commentBody:
Is 11 years long enough to repeat a theme? As Jim Horne of xwordinfo.com points out, nearly the exact same theme appeared on Sunday, Dec. 1, 2013; the only difference (aside from the puzzle size) is that the answers run through the black BACK squares rather than ending on them or starting on them.  (In other words, both the squares before and after the BACK square are part of the same answer, rather than being two different ones.)

But in both cases, BACK is hidden in black squares and both the adjacent across and down squares are involved with each one.  And the 1980 AC/DC album was the revealer in both puzzles.

Discuss amongst yourselves.
Cute theme, but this was the easiest Thursday in a while. I see that the other Steve points out that this a repeat theme, though...
Picked up the theme immediately and sailed through this one. Thought I was in the zone, but it's looking like everybody else is there too.

Maybe I've been doing crosswords for too long, because after I got the revealer, which with the crosses wasn't very difficult, the theme was very obvious, and the rest of the grid filled in too quickly.

This was too straightforward and too easy for me, as I came in at about 45% of my average time.

The clueing was also forgettable, IMHO.

YMMV

As I heard it at the time -- I was volunteering at my college radio station in 1980 -- AC/DC was uncertain as to whether they should disband after the death of Bon Scott. Their consensus was, if any of the others had died, Scott would want to continue on. So they kept going. Back in Black was their next album; they were "back" (recording/touring again) "in black" (while mourning).

while it was a lot easier once i got the theme (which would've been faster if i'd just moved on from the football/soccer clue once i didn't immediately get it), i thoroughly enjoyed it. but it is more wednesday in ease than anything else. i always found (somehow) thursdays to be the hardest, along with fridays - somehow i always do quite well on saturdays but i'm used to thursdays/fridays being my longest. had to leave the puzz to make sure i was doing the right one part way through! i've never finished a thursday in under 15 til now. 


still loved it enough that i'm leaving a comment here for the first time!! i miss meta/themed/whatever-the-word-is puzzles like this. i wonder if there are lists of puzzles for ones that have a trick (one step beyond having a theme, say) but without specifying if it's a rebus, in the black, letter mix-ups etc cause i've seen those but they give too much away based on the category usually.

better yet, a puzzle entirely of clues ending in "?" could be fun, no?
Shouldn't the clue for 6 Down have been "Cheque for a flat?"?  I think so, and only hesitated because it wasn't.  But I was right in the first moment.

That was an awesome puzzle.

Don‚Äôt remember the last time we had a letter hidden in a black square, let alone a rebus. And to have each BACK work for four clues, across and down? That‚Äôs a real feat of construction.

I‚Äôd rather have a ‚ÄúDoner meat dish‚Äù than a ‚ÄúDonner meat dish‚Äù - Which is how I initially read that clue. Yikes!

Thanks for the amazing puzzle, Matthew Faiella!
Quick Thursday, but fun and new.
Great puzzle, Matthew. Fun once I figured out ‚Äúback‚Äù was the missing link. Congratulations on your debut!

Ok let me start out by saying that I have never ever EVER liked AC/DC.  There‚Äôs a lot of great bands that are loud and only know three cords.  AC/DC was never one of them for me.  
So the theme wasn‚Äôt necessarily terrible but‚Ä¶ eh 

Never heard of WIPE OUT, and WARD ‚â† CARE.

Like if someone is your WARD, they‚Äôre in your care I guess?  Weak cluing yet again.

Step it up NYT.   We need a real distraction these days.

The Thursday phantom squares are BACK!

We‚Äôve had black ops, dark matter, a shot in the dark, and bunches of others.

Today‚Äôs was a fun twist on the idea. Hope nobody suffers a black mood because of the trick. Or fall into a black hole. Or give in to fear of the dark.

Sheesh, if a puzzle's gonna have a song as the revealer, we shouldn't have to hunt it down on the internet. https://youtu.be/9vWNauaZAgg?si=7vD5xFIkhbQzLc67 And also we had some more Aussie-adjacent content after yesterday. Are we on the Highway to Hell in a motor coach with a BACKSEAT DRIVER? Or on our way to the OUTBACK? Truthfully, to me the cluing in this wasn't even at a Toughened Up Tuesday level, which always makes me wary, because I'm thinking What am I missing? the whole time. Anyway, even though I'm carping an awful lot here, I did have fun solving this one. Thanks, Matt and congats on the debut.
No complaints!  I like a Thursday. Look forward to it all of Wednesday.
This was fun fun fun! I like it when I understand a theme early enough for it to help. Fun!
Relatively easy to pick up on the theme and to solve, but what a spectacular debut construction feat.  Bravo, Matthew Faiella.
Wow - that was a fun Thursday with 12 answers related to the revealer! An impressive feat of construction. Bravo!
Great puzzle! The themer working both vertically and horizontally was truly impressive - very well done!
Frankly I think just ‚ÄúLESSDRESS‚Äù is more apropos of what often appears on the red carpet than backless.

WOW. I said out loud when I saw the four-way "back." And I kept saying it, over and over again. WOW.

Having my favorite Amy Winehouse song would have made my day on its own. 

But wow. This was next level.
What a debut! I'm rolling out the red carpet for Mr. Faiella.
Welcome to the NYT crossworld, with a standing ovation! And thank you!
üëèüèªüëèüèªüëèüèª

It's funny I was doing a back puzzle from 2017 today that was also a Thursday and also had this weird "BACK" hidden theme in the clues with absolutely no nod to a twist and I was exactly as mad doing that one.

You can't just shoehorn in something like this with no clue. This is lazy puzzle making. You want to be clever? Write a unifying clue that brings it all together.
"You are my sunshine, my only sunshine, you make me happy when skies are gray, you'll never know dear, how much I love you, please don't take my sunshine away."

Congratulations on a fun NYT debut, Mr. Faiella! 

I first figured out that some answers were missing a BACK with [BACK] 
LESS DRESSES. But it took a minute or two longer to realize that all four answers surrounding the [BACK] square included those letters. Very clever indeed!
Loved this puzzle! Amazing work, especially for a debut. So, so fun.

Again my perfectly civil post got withheld or booted by "moderators". Maybe I should go on strike, and ask all of you  to do so, so this gets fixed? Things did not use to be this bad - but only in the past month or two I've had posts delayed or deleted dozens of times. It's beyond annoying, and disrespectful TBH.

A handful of fills were what I thought they would be, and again and again I had to BACK PEDAL, BACK TRACK, BACK OUT and ESCape before I was too committed to a wrong answer to sort it OUT.  KEBAB lookup worked, Capt. America didn't, and I realized I would just have to go it alone and hope for the best.

There were beautiful clues (19A, 27D, and 49D for a few) and some I could only trust to crosses for help with (what do I know about elements?). A surprisingly workable puzzle, but who knew before the music jumped out and the congratulations appeared.  I almost YELLed? 

Matthew Faiella, you are one devil of a debut constructor, and I trust YEW will brew up more‚ÄîI'm sure I'll recover soon and actually get a good night's sleep.   

(Thank you!)
Very clever puzzle. When I realized the ‚¨õ was omnidirectional, I got the smile on my face that Deb was talking about.

Unfortunately the only way I know the periodic table is by singing the Tom Lehrer version in my head (I memorized that instead of paying close enough attention in law school two decades ago), and krypton shows up between argon and neon so that was no help at all. Also explains why I‚Äôm neither a lawyer nor a scientist.
I started in the southeast corner and headed west to find the revealer. From there it was a mooncakewalk back to the start.

It was already clever enough to have the "back in black" motif for the puzzle, but for it to work both ways before and after the square? I agree with the rest in hoping Mr. Faiella comes back soon with another puzzle up his sleeves.

What‚Äôs more fun, that ‚Äúaha‚Äù feeling when you‚Äôve figured out the theme, or that ‚Äúwow‚Äù feeling when you see it‚Äôs even bigger than you realized? 

I was deep into the puzzle before I discovered that the ‚Äúback‚Äù words extended in more than two directions. And when I did, my initial sense of cleverness was replaced by deep respect. (Along with a very large grin.) This was like a slow burn reveal, and in the very best way.

Ok - like Deb, 19A is also my favorite clue and answer, mostly because I do it professionally. Didn‚Äôt think that was possible? I teach racetrack driving. The big difference, and what makes it the best job on planet earth is I‚Äôm usually working on getting my students to drive as fast as they possibly can. Who gets this lucky?

Oh, and great puzzle!

You have every right to be proud, Matthew Faiella. This was a brilliant debut and I hope we will see a great deal more of your work. Sometimes Thursday puzzles contain impressive feats of construction that I admire but that don't actually impact the solving experience . . . in fact you can solve the puzzle without ever getting the trick.  But yours was the opposite--I couldn't have solved the puzzle without light dawning (oh, I see, SET without BACK). And then dawning again (Ohhhh, it goes in all directions), and one more time with the revealer.  I haven't had this much fun on a Thursday in a while.  Chef's kiss.

You should be proud, Matthew,  and I certainly had fun solving your puzzle.  Getting my first BACK was a great AHA moment and of course it was fun to get the others.  It was almost as good as a rebus, my absolute favorite. 

Definitely looking forward to more.

Fun puzzle, clever theme well executed, but the clue for NEE is an editor error. It's not a tag -- it comes before the maiden name (more specifically between two names), e.g. Jaqueline Kennedy, n√©e Bouvier. It literally means "born".

Early in my solve, I started to think, "hmmmm, that seems like more than 3 occurances of BACK."

Nicely executed theme, Matthew.  Hope to see you BACK soon.

Really enjoyable puzzle. Not all that easy for me, of course, but finally catching on to the trick was a big turning point and then just had a great time pondering and figuring out where the 'black' squares would be. Just lots of nice 'aha' moments along the way. Pretty amazing feat of construction.

Oh - and a long time favorite song as well. 

And of course had a puzzle find today. I'll put that in a reply. 

..

Fantastic debut, Matthew!

Love the clueing- 

Those who apply themselves
Motor coaches
Check for a flat

Fun, fun, fun!

Happy Thursday all!
It‚Äôs the Friday of Fridays!
Well Done! Thanks for the aha moments.

Bravo Matthew!  
Took me almost an hour. 
>.<

The type of theme that requires one to imagine something in certain black squares was first used on Feb. 20, 2011, and has now shown up 30 times.  So though it's probably not a stale concept yet, it has become a regular feature of NYT crosswords.  Thursday and Sunday solvers should always  be on the lookout for them.  (Yes, they've been confined to those two days, at least so far.)

Hidden PASSAGES, black OPS, DARK MATTER, black sheep, various ECLIPSES, even doors that open up a maze have been some of the conceits.
i don't do a lot of thursdays but i really enjoyed today! grateful for no rebuses lol

I'm enjoying the crosswords, with or without themes. I'm glad NEE and KOS were mentioned because I couldn't work those out. 

Annoyingly, I thought I was being clever in NOT assuming 'flat' meant 'apartment' and referred to a flat tyre! 

I thought 'bone' for courage was an American term, and 'less dress' referred to stars wearing revealing clothes! (quite clever) so didn't cotton on to the presence of a theme. As for 'seat drivers'? Another mysterious term from the US.

I need to use knowledge of the language when general knowledge doesn't help. Could Britney be singing about Topic, Tonic, or Toxic? Aha, this gave me the bakery call, which I didn't know. I was sidetracked by thinking of a word joining call and bakery items, which would be a cryptic clue. Soup and salad? Got it from the crossers but not something I would think of, since soup is a winter and salad is a summer dish. 
Great fun.

Cpt.Q will be happy to see invertebrates getting the near-spanner recognition for courageously giving it their all.


The joys of small cities and towns: quiet bakeries.
Loved this puzzle!

Thank you, Matthew Faiella, for making your theme matter!

Usually (almost always?) puzzles' themes/tricks seem to be more about constructors creating challenges for themselves rather than for solvers. This results in grids solvers can fill while remaining completely clueless about the themes.

Your puzzle almost requires solvers to figure out the trick, so thanks again, Mr. Faiella, for creating an excellent puzzle with a useful theme!
I got the trick pretty early on and from there it was just filling in the blanks. That is not to say I didn‚Äôt enjoy the puzzle because I did.

This puzzle provided three solving elements that I love, which today‚Äôs theme has inspired me to name:

‚Ä¢	BACKTRACKING.  Being on the hunt for the Thursday Trick, that sweet befuddlement of trying to crack what is afoot, that inner feeling that if I keep on, there will be closure, and, perhaps, even a ‚Ä¶
‚Ä¢	FLASHBACK.  The big bang when you see it, when you crack the riddle, when all becomes clear, that glorious release of tension, that sometimes leads to a ‚Ä¶
‚Ä¢	BACKSPLASH.  The glorious sled ride of a splat fill.

The ‚ÄúWha?‚Äù, the ‚ÄúWow‚Äù and the ‚ÄúWhee!‚Äù ‚Äì all in the box today.  

I like the serendipitous theme echo in the first row as well, with two answers, SLAP and WARD, that can pair with BACK.  

Matthew, you showed you have the constructing chops, working out a design to cleanly accommodate the dozen BACK answers plus the revealer.  But constructing chops are only worthwhile if the solving experience shines, and for me, today, it sparkled.  Thank you, sir, congratulations on your debut, and please, don‚Äôt be a stranger!
excellent puzz-- this got me absolutely fired up to listen to some HARD ROCK on this wonderful thursday ü§ò

Great Thursday entry!  I really enjoyed this one.  The best part is that even though I caught on to the theme quickly, I was still both surprised and delighted when I reached the revealer.  What a perfect crossword idea!   And well executed.  How is it even possible that no constructor thought to use this one before?

Some really beautiful non-theme cluing too:

"Levels in a ring" - great misdirection
"Those who apply themselves" - good
"Check for a flat" - excellent!!

And apparently this is a debut, too.  Way to enter the fray, man.  Nice job, Mr. Faiella!  You really applied yourself.  :)

____________________
Jesse Goldberg 8/28/2024 for Puzzle of the Decade
(emu filler)
come 'back' soon...  Well played, Deb.

Congratulations to Matthew Faiella for a brilliant debut puzzle! Masterful constructing! I did require a few lookups to solve, but I expect that on a Thursday. 

H Mart (5D) and the French stew (24A) were new to me. I also had the wrong letters for the [W. Coast hub for United Airlines] in 33D. Oh well! Great start for my Thursday!

At the risk of sounding like the Anti-Lewis, IMHO what was essentially a clever gimmick was marred by a grid design in which some, but not all, of the isolated black squares held [BACK]. Surprised the editors didn't ask Mr. Faiella to tweak his grid. Matthew is clearly already an impressive constructor, so maybe the eds. just didn't have enough [back]bo√±e.

Hi Deb! --You don't have to make a verb out of WARD to make the clue work: [Care] can be a noun, as in M-W. n.6: "a person or thing that is an object of attention, anxiety, or solicitude". Not my first thought, but neither I nor Judge Turpin had problems with the clue.
Fun, fun, fun!

Speaking of "come back"... the strikers have returned (but wihout a contract.)  I must say I missed hearing what everyone thought of the puzzles (and also saved some time for other things...)  I contributed to the guild and continued to do the puzzles I have paid for...

So...I need to check the answer key to be sure I got a couple of spots.  Nice puzzle, clever trick, enjoyable entries, but Britney Spears (ugh, plus 2004??) and the clue/entry at 4A (which I didn't 'get') were stumpers for me.

I also thought 'Region of the brain' should have a more exact name (Broca's Area, hippocampus, medulla oblongata, etc.), rather than a broad general term, given the wording of the clue.
Oh well.

PhysicsDaughter is here (early oncology appt,.. so, rather than drive for an hour EAST in rush hour traffic into the rising sun, she spent the night.)  And now I see I finished with a wrong letter...  She knew the song.  Tsk.  But she's stuck at 4A.  Nyah nyah.
Kudos to Mr. Faiella. What a great debut!
One of my favourites in recent memory. So clever and well put together üëèüèæ üëèüèæ
This was just great! It was fun, funny, smooth... everything one might want in a crossword. Wonderful job!

I'm always humbled when I finish a Thursday fast, only to find that my understanding of the theme was partial at best. 

I appreciated only three of the "BACK"-containing clues. (BACKSEATDRIVERS; BACKLESSDRESS; BACKTRACK)

Only when I read Deb's explanation did I realize there were 12.

So only a partial victory.

I figured out pretty quickly that the black square hid ‚ÄúBACK‚Äù, and my general thought was ‚Äòmeh‚Äô as a theme. 

And then I realized all four clues fed into BACK, and I saw how much more fun and more impressive the theme was! Awesome!

Also, I was so, so confident that ‚ÄúCheck for a flat?‚Äù solved to TUNE, going down the musical path. That tripped me up for a while.

WARD/WIPEOUT/VEAU was my KRYPTONite. Had to check the solution to finish.  Great debut and thanks.  

Constructor of today's Mini is Ian Livengood who we've not seen here since 2016.  Perhaps a big puzzle in the works?

Strands #256
‚ÄúName of the game‚Äù
üîµüîµüîµüîµ
üîµüîµüü°

After yesterday's fun one, I decided to give it a go again today. I liked this one, too! Count me a fan of the more obtuse themes. 

PLEASE, NO SPOILERS until after the View All Replies button.
28 down on the 11/14 crossword, years in uruguay. Anos and A√±os are two very different words. I know the √ë wouldnt show up in the grid but, Anos in uruguay has a very different meaning
Such a fun theme!
Yaaaas I figured out what the theme was before even getting to the revealer and got my best Thursday score to date!

(2nd post)
This puzzle reminded of that SPCA fundraiser gala I attended in Erie, PA, back in the summer of 1980. It was an elegant affair, the wealthy donors pulling up in their BMWs, the women showing off their torsos in backless evening dresses. Dinner was an outdoor affair, the tables spread out under a grove of pine, beech, and yew, the quiet of the scene punctuated only by the cries of the jays high up in the trees. 

The menu was a salad of Asian baby greens, followed by a blanquette de tofu, and, being summer, a dessert of refreshing flavored ice.

As I said, and elegant affair; but my cynical self couldn't help but wonder whether some of the funds collected to Save the Lemurs and Lions, weren't being funneled as kickbacks to the organizers.

So, Matthew now has his BACKa laureate in puzzle construction. He must have used a way BACK machine, otherwise it would have been BACKbreaking. Twelve themers, wow.

It took me a week to break the puzzle habit, but I guess the tech strike is over now, so I'm BACK.  For a day or two, then I'll be off line for a week or so.

Outstanding debut, wonderful!
Oddly enough I had LONG at first for division/number and I thought I had a great answer for ‚Äúcheck for a flat‚Äù‚ÄîTUNE.
When I saw the grid design and read the revealed, I immediately thought ‚ÄúStairway to Heaven.‚Äù
Loved this one! Favourite Thursday ever I reckon.
Twigged to the "back" thing early on, and only thought "wow there are quite a few". Didn't appreciate how well crafted it was, until I finished. Bravo for a debut on a Thursday!

The previous BACKINBLACK puzzle was mentioned in the first comment today, but no link to it was provided. It was a quite remarkable puzzle. Here are a few of the theme answers (and the 'black' was just a black square as in today's puzzle): THEREANDBACKAGAIN HUMPBACKWHALE PAPERBACKBOOK BROKEBACKMOUNTAIN TURNSBACKTHECLOCK WONTBACKDOWN FEEDBACKLOOP BENDOVERBACKWARDS Pretty amazing. Here's the Xword Info link: https://www.xwordinfo.com/Crossword?date=12/1/2013&g=98&d=A ...

I wonder if Spanish speakers always snicker every time that the language‚Äôs word for ‚Äúyear‚Äù is the answer, since crosswords ignore accent marks.

On another pedantic (and surprisingly gross and gastrointestinal) note, I don‚Äôt think the clue for 14A is strictly accurate (though it‚Äôs hardly an impediment to solving). While the ‚ÄúTO‚Äù certainly does mean ‚Äúbean,‚Äù the ‚ÄúFU‚Äù in TOFU is written with a Chinese character that generally means ‚Äúto rot‚Äù (even though that‚Äôs not a truly accurate description of how the food in question is made, unless further processed).

The Japanese version of Wikipedia cites texts from ancient China (where both the food itself and the word for it originate) that suggest that the usage of ‚Äúrot‚Äù is because dried soybeans themselves are hard both in texture and to digest, but (unpressed, unformed) TOFU is somewhat similar to what happens when stomach acid and enzymes break the hard, dried beans down into a slurry that is like how animal meat breaks down into a sludge when left to rot. This is pretty much the exact opposite meaning of ‚Äúcurd‚Äù/‚Äúcurdle,‚Äù which describes a product/process where an additive (an acid or rennet, in the case of cheeses) causes something already fluid to coagulate into something more solid.

Thus, although ‚Äúbean curd‚Äù is a perfectly accurate description of what TOFU actually is, it isn‚Äôt the literal meaning, either etymologically speaking or how anyone in the greater Sinosphere would perceive the word at a glance.
That was awesome! Really fun to complete. Most of the clues were straightforward, but those that weren‚Äôt, like 19A and 27D, enhanced the puzzle.
Fun puzzle today, I figured out the ‚Äúback in black‚Äù pretty quick and was just waiting for the clue. Nice and fun fill - nice work!

My initial confusion (are there rebuses?) was cleared by the rock-n-rollin' revealer clue (46A).
I was very impressed by the 4-way "backs". 

A great Thursday puzzle, very enjoyable!
Absolutely terrific!
What a fun puzz. Thursdays are always a treat!
What a fun puzzle. My aha moment came with the FULL answer. Any day I can get through a Thursday puzzle in one sitting is a good day.
So clever!  Didn't get it until I solved it.   Very enjoyable.
‚ÄúBeer me‚Äù is a phrase that comes to mind when listening to AC/DC‚Äôs blues riffs and chugging beat.

Matthew sure gets a lot of mileage out of only three rebus squares, doesn't he?

I was w-a-a-y ahead of the game today as I saw the well-clued SETBACK immediately.  What other answer can there be to "temporary defeat" after all? I first wondered whether SET would be written in upside down as TES -- but the very easy LAS and OMIT disabused me of that notion.  so then I looked for a rebus square.  And it would have to be black.

Black rebus squares don't faze me.  My first puzzle -- the one that put me on the map, so to speak -- featured a single black rebus square.  Now on to some of the other answers in the puzzle:

LESS DRESS is "red carpet attire"?  Does that mean that nudity is the dressiest option of all?

I first had siNK for the precipitous drop in the stock market price.  ALES forced me to change to sANK -- but the verb tense is wrong.  How can that be?  Oh, I SEE: it's TANK.

Lovely clues for BACKSEAT DRIVERS and JOBSEEKERS.

For those of us well-versed in rebuses, this puzzle was probably a piece of cake.  For other solvers -- practice on this one; it's one of the easier you'll see.  I enjoyed it -- and I applaud the theme density.

My grandmother's maiden name was Goudzwaard, which, I'm reliably informed, is Dutch for "In the care of God." So 4A works for me. Also, my dad's middle name was WARD, as an Americanized nod to her side of the family.

Yeah, I didn't get the gimmick until I saw the Surya Bonaly clue. I knew for sure that her signature move was a BACKFLIP. If I recall correctly, she didn't get credit for doing it in the Olympics, because it wasn't an "approved" move, per the federation. But she did it anyway, for the fans.

A fun puzzle. Did not know "Back in black." Completed most of the puzzle without filling in "Black" mentally. Could not understand why a courageous person needed "bone." Loved that red carpet attire was "less dress." Actually laughed out loud at that one! Actually using "back in black" (not exactly the way Matthew did but close enough) helped with "outback," "back pedal," and "didn't hold back" and I finished the puzzle in less than my average. I loved the square of L's in the southwest. Well done, and, as at least one other person said, appreciated all the more when I saw the complete answers.

Getting 12 answers out of three "rebus" squares is impressive! Beautifully constructed.

I was sure that HEME was HEMOGLOBIN and that's where a rebus was hiding, but it just didn't make sense. Solving the revealer helped spot my error pretty early though :)

I found this incredible and incredibly fun! 

Although I'm still a little bummed they rejected my similar puzzle with the revealer "Rhapsody in Blue".

Maybe because I only had one theme answer?
Very fun puzzle! Tricky, but not confounding! Kudos!

I liked this one, but am embarrassed how long it took me to realize what was going on. I thought the three long clues were missing the word back, but then I kept finding other ones that were missing back and was confused because the clue only said it was in three places, and that was a lot more than three clues missing the word back. I didn't realize until I was basically done with the puzzle that it was three black squares that had the word back in them.
What an amazing debut! One of my favorite puzzles for a long time; hopefully everyone else had as much fun with that as I did.

A clever revealer that leads to 12, count 'em 12!, themed clues.  Wow!

Hats off to you, Matt Faiella.  Come back anytime!
Super fun one today! I was bracing myself for another Thursday eye-roller, but this one was a breeze. Hope to see Matthew back soon!
Thoroughly enjoyable puzzle!  And that album was one of my favorites üòÑ
Congratulations on a terrific debut!  Hope to see more of your work.

This is one of those gimmicks that's so utterly intuitive and fun that it's kind of shocking nobody's done this exact Thursday trick before. 

I enjoyed every bit of this puzzle: The construction was beautiful, the trick was tough to figure out but simple and fun once you did. The clues themselves were great. The difficulty was just right for a Thursday (I clocked in with a good-but-not-great time).

Kudos to Mr. Faiella. 5/5 No-doubter!
Nice job on your debut! This is another one of those clever puzzles that makes me want to try my hand at a puzzle, just so that I can see it come together as beautifully as this one did!

After skimming through the 108 Comments currently available, I must assume that I'm the only one puzzled by the colored blob that covered the grid once finished.

My CI has progressed beyond that point. I barely finished the puzzle in 11:40:33 taking full advantage of Autocheck, and utterly failed to read the crucial black squares! I won't be around much longer,

The Back in Black clue said it relates to 3 other clues, but those were only the across clues.  There were a number of vertical clues that used back in black, too, eh?  [Back] Track, Stand [Back], etc.  Oops! You sold the creator short.  Others may have noted this but I'm not going to read through 176 comments to find out.
Just incredible! Twelve themed clues, engaging fill, not much obscure knowledge or crosswordese. Certainly hope for more puzzles like this in the future.

I'm not that good at the later-in-the-week puzzles and had to come to the comments for a clue, but once I realised that it was a four way intersection I in-real-life smiled. And yes, the "Motor Coaches" clue is genius!

Such a great Thursday puzzle! Love how consistently applied the theme is. Really well done.

P.S. I‚Äôm always a bit confused by solvers who say they didn‚Äôt get the theme until the end, as I can‚Äôt imagine ever being able to solve these without first clearing the ‚Äúaha!‚Äù moment. Is there some common method of solving that just ignores clues altogether, or quickly assumes cluing might be wonky and just autocompletes words? Otherwise how would SET, LESS DRESS, KICK, TRACK, etc work?
Excellent puzzle. Had a blast figuring this out. I have BACK IN BLACK on vinyl and you can bet I will be putting it on when I get home from work.

This was challenging but a lot of fun.

At first I thought I was toast, but everything fell into place bit by bit.

Once I got the theme and realized it applied to more than three answers, I  was golden.

Thanks for a great puzzle!

What an amazing debut puzzle for Matthew Faiella! It both challenged me and made me smile at a time when it‚Äôs a bit tough to find reasons to smile. Thanks to the whole team for bringing this to us. I did catch on early, in that top NW corner but it still took me some time to realize that the BACKs worked in all four directions. I haven‚Äôt read all of Deb‚Äôs comments yet or the comments from other solvers‚Äîhave to get out for my daily hike before the rains come. But I had to pop in and say how much I loved this puzzle.

Top ten puzzle for sure, and a debut to boot! Absolutely loved this one. (BACK)LESSDRESS was my entry point to the theme, and though I started off dropping the extra letters in as a rebus, it soon became clear that wasn‚Äôt going to work for the downs, and then everything clicked and the rest of the puzzle was one smile after another. Love Thursdays!
Oh boy. A different cutesy gimmick.

Nice one!  It took me an embarrassingly long time to figure out the "back in black" gimmicke (even after I'd filled in that answer!)

For some reason I had trouble with a subsection of the top left quadrant, in no small part because I had HOLD for 12D  and so instead of KRY I had DRY for the element clue.  Anyway after recharging my batteries overnight, I saw the hook, got DIDNT HOLD (BACK), the UT of WIPEOUT gave me the aha for that one, and I had it solved lickety split.

I'm looking forward to more puzzles from Mr. Faiella!
Clever - yet I wouldn‚Äôt have figured out the hidden BACK in the black squares if I hadn‚Äôt first read the opening paragraphs of the article.

I am so proud of myself that I solved my first Thursday crossword puzzle here today - and such a nice one at that! I needed a hint from Deb though, not being a native speaker sometimes makes me doubt my abilities when faced with any kind of wordplay. But after realizing that my LESSDRESS actually had a meaning, the rest of the clues all fell into place. Very satsfying solve!
Amazing debut. Brilliant Thursday construction. I knew the album and got it early, so the theme was very easy for me. Nice to see my place of birth in the grid!
Brilliant puzzle!
Matthew, this is a seriously clever puzzle ‚Äì well done!
Very well done! Tanked my time, but worth it.
Honestly, I usually hate Thursdays (Fridays and Saturdays are my jam), but I loved this one! Thanks for making me see how the rebuses can be fun sometimes!
There's clever that's annoying and there's clever that's fun.  This one was fun!

Just letting those who may care know I probably will not be posting here any more, or not doing it regularly anyway - I've just had it with the "moderation". I spend a long time writing a comment - because many people here seem to enjoy my outlook on these puzzles - and then it just does not appear for no obvious reason. I've had this happen many times over the past few weeks, also today. Apparently posts being "moderated for civility" means they get randomly quashed. If only I got some feedback as to what the reason was - but no! That is apparently too much to ask. So bye, or bye for now at least, it's been fun.
Deb, Thanks again for making le go the extra mile such as it is, to figure it out for myself. Just hd trouble Round the mid top for some reason. With WARD for ‚ÄúCare‚Äù and then eventually.
A delicious Thursday! More please!
What a great Thursday after a week away from the grids. I, too, love a punny clue, even though I hate puns IRL. I enjoy how they ask my mind to be more flexible!
What fun! Great debut, Matthew!

I‚Äôm fairly new to solving, so I followed all the advice in the article about how to solve the crosswords. I‚Äôve been tackling the archives and I get through at least 5 a day. Turns out, Thursday puzzles are my favorite and I think this one is superb! It was great fun solving it and not just because I love AC/DC!

I stared at my screen in total disbelief -- this is literally the theme of the of the crossword puzzle I've been creating for the past 3 months and was just about ready to submit to the NYT. Well, time to find a new hobby.

The rookie hits it out of the park on the first pitch. I can almost hear Matthew singing: ‚ÄúSo look at me now / I‚Äôm just makin‚Äô my play / Don‚Äôt try to push your luck, just get out of my way‚Ä¶‚Äù

ha ha ha, Deb Amlin - I hope he comes back, too!

In 2016, Hasbro introduced Dr. Orchid in place of Mrs. White.
